trans-unit.source: How to use Queue storage from Java | Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: How to use Queue storage from Java | Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: Learn how to use the Azure Queue service to create and delete queues, and insert, get, and delete messages. Samples written in Java.
trans-unit.target: Learn how to use the Azure Queue service to create and delete queues, and insert, get, and delete messages. Samples written in Java.

trans-unit.source: This guide will show you how to perform common scenarios using the Azure Queue storage service.
trans-unit.target: This guide will show you how to perform common scenarios using the Azure Queue storage service.

trans-unit.source: The samples are written in Java and use the <linkText>Azure Storage SDK for Java</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: The samples are written in Java and use the <linkText>Azure Storage SDK for Java</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: The scenarios covered include inserting, peeking, getting, and deleting queue messages, as well as creating and deleting queues.
trans-unit.target: The scenarios covered include inserting, peeking, getting, and deleting queue messages, as well as creating and deleting queues.

trans-unit.source: For more information on queues, see the <linkText>Next steps</linkText><title></title> section.
trans-unit.target: For more information on queues, see the <linkText>Next steps</linkText><title></title> section.

trans-unit.source: Note: An SDK is available for developers who are using Azure Storage on Android devices.
trans-unit.target: Note: An SDK is available for developers who are using Azure Storage on Android devices.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see the <linkText>Azure Storage SDK for Android</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For more information, see the <linkText>Azure Storage SDK for Android</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: In this guide, you will use storage features which can be run within a Java application locally, or in code running within a web role or worker role in Azure.
trans-unit.target: In this guide, you will use storage features which can be run within a Java application locally, or in code running within a web role or worker role in Azure.

trans-unit.source: To do so, you will need to install the Java Development Kit (JDK) and create an Azure storage account in your Azure subscription.
trans-unit.target: To do so, you will need to install the Java Development Kit (JDK) and create an Azure storage account in your Azure subscription.

trans-unit.source: Once you have done so, you will need to verify that your development system meets the minimum requirements and dependencies which are listed in the <linkText>Azure Storage SDK for Java</linkText><title></title> repository on GitHub.
trans-unit.target: Once you have done so, you will need to verify that your development system meets the minimum requirements and dependencies which are listed in the <linkText>Azure Storage SDK for Java</linkText><title></title> repository on GitHub.

trans-unit.source: If your system meets those requirements, you can follow the instructions for downloading and installing the Azure Storage Libraries for Java on your system from that repository.
trans-unit.target: If your system meets those requirements, you can follow the instructions for downloading and installing the Azure Storage Libraries for Java on your system from that repository.

trans-unit.source: Once you have completed those tasks, you will be able to create a Java application which uses the examples in this article.
trans-unit.target: Once you have completed those tasks, you will be able to create a Java application which uses the examples in this article.

trans-unit.source: Add the following import statements to the top of the Java file where you want to use Azure storage APIs to access queues:
trans-unit.target: Add the following import statements to the top of the Java file where you want to use Azure storage APIs to access queues:

trans-unit.source: An Azure storage client uses a storage connection string to store endpoints and credentials for accessing data management services.
trans-unit.target: An Azure storage client uses a storage connection string to store endpoints and credentials for accessing data management services.

trans-unit.source: When running in a client application, you must provide the storage connection string in the following format, using the name of your storage account and the Primary access key for the storage account listed in the Management Portal for the AccountName and AccountKey values.
trans-unit.target: When running in a client application, you must provide the storage connection string in the following format, using the name of your storage account and the Primary access key for the storage account listed in the Management Portal for the AccountName and AccountKey values.

trans-unit.source: This example shows how you can declare a static field to hold the connection string:
trans-unit.target: This example shows how you can declare a static field to hold the connection string:

trans-unit.source: In an application running within a role in Microsoft Azure, this string can be stored in the service configuration file, ServiceConfiguration.cscfg, and can be accessed with a call to the RoleEnvironment.getConfigurationSettings method.
trans-unit.target: In an application running within a role in Microsoft Azure, this string can be stored in the service configuration file, ServiceConfiguration.cscfg, and can be accessed with a call to the RoleEnvironment.getConfigurationSettings method.

trans-unit.source: Here's an example of getting the connection string from a Setting element named StorageConnectionString in the service configuration file:
trans-unit.target: Here's an example of getting the connection string from a Setting element named StorageConnectionString in the service configuration file:

trans-unit.source: The following samples assume that you have used one of these two methods to get the storage connection string.
trans-unit.target: The following samples assume that you have used one of these two methods to get the storage connection string.

trans-unit.source: A CloudQueueClient object lets you get reference objects for queues.
trans-unit.target: A CloudQueueClient object lets you get reference objects for queues.

trans-unit.source: The following code creates a CloudQueueClient object.
trans-unit.target: The following code creates a CloudQueueClient object.

trans-unit.source: (Note: There are additional ways to create CloudStorageAccount objects; for more information, see CloudStorageAccount in the [Azure Storage Client SDK Reference].)
trans-unit.target: (Note: There are additional ways to create CloudStorageAccount objects; for more information, see CloudStorageAccount in the [Azure Storage Client SDK Reference].)

trans-unit.source: Use the CloudQueueClient object to get a reference to the queue you want to use.
trans-unit.target: Use the CloudQueueClient object to get a reference to the queue you want to use.

trans-unit.source: You can create the queue if it doesn't exist.
trans-unit.target: You can create the queue if it doesn't exist.

trans-unit.source: To insert a message into an existing queue, first create a new CloudQueueMessage.
trans-unit.target: To insert a message into an existing queue, first create a new CloudQueueMessage.

trans-unit.source: Next, call the addMessage method.
trans-unit.target: Next, call the addMessage method.

trans-unit.source: A CloudQueueMessage can be created from either a string (in UTF-8 format) or a byte array.
trans-unit.target: A CloudQueueMessage can be created from either a string (in UTF-8 format) or a byte array.

trans-unit.source: Here is code which creates a queue (if it doesn't exist) and inserts the message "Hello, World".
trans-unit.target: Here is code which creates a queue (if it doesn't exist) and inserts the message "Hello, World".

trans-unit.source: You can peek at the message in the front of a queue without removing it from the queue by calling peekMessage.
trans-unit.target: You can peek at the message in the front of a queue without removing it from the queue by calling peekMessage.

trans-unit.source: You can change the contents of a message in-place in the queue.
trans-unit.target: You can change the contents of a message in-place in the queue.

trans-unit.source: If the message represents a work task, you could use this feature to update the status of the work task.
trans-unit.target: If the message represents a work task, you could use this feature to update the status of the work task.

trans-unit.source: The following code updates the queue message with new contents, and sets the visibility timeout to extend another 60 seconds.
trans-unit.target: The following code updates the queue message with new contents, and sets the visibility timeout to extend another 60 seconds.

trans-unit.source: This saves the state of work associated with the message, and gives the client another minute to continue working on the message.
trans-unit.target: This saves the state of work associated with the message, and gives the client another minute to continue working on the message.

trans-unit.source: You could use this technique to track multi-step workflows on queue messages, without having to start over from the beginning if a processing step fails due to hardware or software failure.
trans-unit.target: You could use this technique to track multi-step workflows on queue messages, without having to start over from the beginning if a processing step fails due to hardware or software failure.

trans-unit.source: Typically, you would keep a retry count as well, and if the message is retried more than n times, you would delete it.
trans-unit.target: Typically, you would keep a retry count as well, and if the message is retried more than n times, you would delete it.

trans-unit.source: This protects against a message that triggers an application error each time it is processed.
trans-unit.target: This protects against a message that triggers an application error each time it is processed.

trans-unit.source: The following code sample searches through the queue of messages, locates the first message that matches "Hello, World" for the content, then modifies the message content and exits.
trans-unit.target: The following code sample searches through the queue of messages, locates the first message that matches "Hello, World" for the content, then modifies the message content and exits.

trans-unit.source: Alternatively, the following code sample updates just the first visible message on the queue.
trans-unit.target: Alternatively, the following code sample updates just the first visible message on the queue.

trans-unit.source: You can get an estimate of the number of messages in a queue.
trans-unit.target: You can get an estimate of the number of messages in a queue.

trans-unit.source: The downloadAttributes method asks the Queue service for several current values, including a count of how many messages are in a queue.
trans-unit.target: The downloadAttributes method asks the Queue service for several current values, including a count of how many messages are in a queue.

trans-unit.source: The count is only approximate because messages can be added or removed after the Queue service responds to your request.
trans-unit.target: The count is only approximate because messages can be added or removed after the Queue service responds to your request.

trans-unit.source: The getApproximateMessageCount method returns the last value retrieved by the call to downloadAttributes, without calling the Queue service.
trans-unit.target: The getApproximateMessageCount method returns the last value retrieved by the call to downloadAttributes, without calling the Queue service.

trans-unit.source: Your code dequeues a message from a queue in two steps.
trans-unit.target: Your code dequeues a message from a queue in two steps.

trans-unit.source: When you call retrieveMessage, you get the next message in a queue.
trans-unit.target: When you call retrieveMessage, you get the next message in a queue.

trans-unit.source: A message returned from retrieveMessage becomes invisible to any other code reading messages from this queue.
trans-unit.target: A message returned from retrieveMessage becomes invisible to any other code reading messages from this queue.

trans-unit.source: By default, this message stays invisible for 30 seconds.
trans-unit.target: By default, this message stays invisible for 30 seconds.

trans-unit.source: To finish removing the message from the queue, you must also call deleteMessage.
trans-unit.target: To finish removing the message from the queue, you must also call deleteMessage.

trans-unit.source: This two-step process of removing a message assures that if your code fails to process a message due to hardware or software failure, another instance of your code can get the same message and try again.
trans-unit.target: This two-step process of removing a message assures that if your code fails to process a message due to hardware or software failure, another instance of your code can get the same message and try again.

trans-unit.source: Your code calls deleteMessage right after the message has been processed.
trans-unit.target: Your code calls deleteMessage right after the message has been processed.

trans-unit.source: There are two ways you can customize message retrieval from a queue.
trans-unit.target: There are two ways you can customize message retrieval from a queue.

trans-unit.source: First, you can get a batch of messages (up to 32).
trans-unit.target: First, you can get a batch of messages (up to 32).

trans-unit.source: Second, you can set a longer or shorter invisibility timeout, allowing your code more or less time to fully process each message.
trans-unit.target: Second, you can set a longer or shorter invisibility timeout, allowing your code more or less time to fully process each message.

trans-unit.source: The following code example uses the retrieveMessages method to get 20 messages in one call.
trans-unit.target: The following code example uses the retrieveMessages method to get 20 messages in one call.

trans-unit.source: Then it processes each message using a for loop.
trans-unit.target: Then it processes each message using a for loop.

trans-unit.source: It also sets the invisibility timeout to five minutes (300 seconds) for each message.
trans-unit.target: It also sets the invisibility timeout to five minutes (300 seconds) for each message.

trans-unit.source: Note that the five minutes starts for all messages at the same time, so when five minutes have passed since the call to retrieveMessages, any messages which have not been deleted will become visible again.
trans-unit.target: Note that the five minutes starts for all messages at the same time, so when five minutes have passed since the call to retrieveMessages, any messages which have not been deleted will become visible again.

trans-unit.source: To obtain a list of the current queues, call the CloudQueueClient.listQueues() method, which will return a collection of CloudQueue objects.
trans-unit.target: To obtain a list of the current queues, call the CloudQueueClient.listQueues() method, which will return a collection of CloudQueue objects.

trans-unit.source: To delete a queue and all the messages contained in it, call the deleteIfExists method on the CloudQueue object.
trans-unit.target: To delete a queue and all the messages contained in it, call the deleteIfExists method on the CloudQueue object.

trans-unit.source: Now that you've learned the basics of queue storage, follow these links to learn about more complex storage tasks.
trans-unit.target: Now that you've learned the basics of queue storage, follow these links to learn about more complex storage tasks.
